Blockchain Assisted Decentralized Federated LearningÂ (BLADE-FL): Performance Analysis and Resource Allocation

JunÂ Li, YumengÂ Shao, KangÂ Wei, MingÂ Ding, ChuanÂ Ma, LongÂ Shi, Zhu Han, and H.Â VincentÂ Poor J. Li, Y. Shao, K. Wei, C. Ma, and L. Shi are with the School of Electronic and Optical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, 210094, China. E-mail: {jun.li, shaoyumeng, kang.wei, chuan.ma}@njust.edu.cn, slong1007@gmail.com. M. Ding is with Data61, CSIRO, Sydney, Australia. E-mail: ming.ding@data61.csiro.au. Z. Han is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Houston, Houston, TX, USA. E-mail: hanzhu22@gmail.com. H.Â V.Â Poor is with Department of Electrical Engineering, Princeton University, NJ, USA. E-mail: poor@princeton.edu.
Abstract

Federated learningÂ (FL), as a distributed machine learning paradigm, promotes personal privacy by local data processing at each client. However, relying on a centralized server for model aggregation, standard FL is vulnerable to server malfunctions, untrustworthy server, and external attacks. To address this issue, we propose a decentralized FL framework by integrating blockchain into FL, namely, blockchain assisted decentralized federated learningÂ (BLADE-FL). In a round of the proposed BLADE-FL, each client broadcasts the trained model to other clients, aggregates its own model with received ones, and then competes to generate a block before its local training of the next round. We evaluate the learning performance of BLADE-FL, and develop an upper bound on the global loss function. Then we verify that this bound is convex with respect to the number of overall aggregation rounds Kğ¾K, and optimize the computing resource allocation for minimizing the upper bound. We also note that there is a critical problem of training deficiency, caused by lazy clients who plagiarize othersâ€™ trained models and add artificial noises to disguise their cheating behaviors. Focusing on this problem, we explore the impact of lazy clients on the learning performance of BLADE-FL, and characterize the relationship among the optimal Kğ¾K, the learning parameters, and the proportion of lazy clients. Based on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST datasets, we show that the experimental results are consistent with the analytical ones. To be specific, the gap between the developed upper bound and experimental results is lower than 5%percent55\%, and the optimized Kğ¾K based on the upper bound can effectively minimize the loss function.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, blockchain, lazy client, computing resource allocation

1 Introduction

With the development of the Internet of ThingsÂ (IoT), the amount of data from end devices is exploding at an unprecedented rate. Conventional machine learning (ML) technologies encounter the problem of how to efficiently collect distributed data from various IoT devices for centralized processingÂ [1]. To tackle the issue raised by transmission bottleneck, distributed machine learningÂ (DML) has emerged to process data at the network edge in a distributive mannerÂ [2]. DML can alleviate the burden on the central server by dividing a task into sub-tasks assigned to multiple nodes. However, DML needs to exchange samples when training a taskÂ [3], posing a serious risk of privacy leakageÂ [4]. As such, federated learning (FL)Â [5], proposed by Google as a novel DML paradigm, shows its potential advantagesÂ [6]. In a FL system, a machine learning model is trained across multiple distributed clients with local datasets and then aggregated on a centralized server. FL is able to cooperatively implement machine learning tasks without raw data transmissions, thereby promoting clientsâ€™ data privacyÂ [7, 8, 9]. FL has been applied to various data-sensitive scenarios, such as smart health-care, E-commerceÂ [10], and the Google project GboardÂ [11].

However, due to centralized aggregations of models, standard FL is vulnerable to server malfunctions and external attacks, incurring either inaccurate model updates or even training failures. In order to solve this single-point-failure issue, blockchainÂ [12, 13, 14] has been applied to FL systems. Leveraging advantages of blockchain techniques, the work inÂ [15] developed a blockchain-enabled FL architecture to validate the uploaded parameters and investigated system performance, such as block generation rate and learning latency. Most of the works [16, 17, 18] have introduced a third-party blockchain network into FL systems, to benefit from a fully decentralized network at the expense of extra mining delay and mining consumption. Since model aggregations are fulfilled by miners in a decentralized manner, the blockchained FL can solve the single-point-failure problem. In addition, owing to a validation process of local training, FL can be extended to untrustworthy devices in a public networkÂ [19].

To protect privacy and security of FL systems, the work in [20] developed a tamper-proof architecture that utilized blockchain to enhance system security when sharing parameters, and proposed a novel consensus mechanism, i.e., Proof of QualityÂ (PoQ), to optimize reward function. The work in [21] protected privacy of blockchained FL by using local differential privacy, and stand against poisoning attack by executing smart contract. The work in [22] applied consortium blockchain and Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT) consensus algorithm into blockchained FL, to ensure the network reliability and safety with a trusted committee. The work in [23] investigated the robustness of blockchained FL against certain percentage of member attacks, and proposed a corresponding defence mechanism to protect the system. The work in [24] proposed an autonomous blockchain based FL design for privacy-aware and efficient vehicular communication network, and achieved the system-level performance by adjusting parameters such as block size, block arrival rate, and retransmission limit.

Later, other works have investigated different directions of blockchain assisted FL. For example, the work in [25] proposed an incentive mechanism to encourage clients to follow the protocol of blockchained FL. The recent work in [26] modeled the computation and communication resource in the blockchained FL, and improved the utility between learning performance and resource consumption by controlling the number of local iterations in FL. The work in [27] showed the energy consumption model, and optimized the performance by allocating energy resources. The work inÂ  [28] applied blockchained FL into industrial IoT for device failure detection, so that the system can be applied in reality.

Although the above mentioned works resorted to blockchain architecture for avoiding single-point-failure, they inevitably introduced a third-party, i.e., miners rooted from blockchain, to store the aggregated models distributively, causing potential information leakage. Also, these works did not analyze the convergence performance of model training, which is important for evaluating FL learning performance. In addition, the consumption of resources, e.g., computing capability, caused by mining in blockchainÂ [29] is generally not taken into account in these works. However, resources consumed by mining are not negligible compared with those consumed by FL model trainingÂ [13], especially when mining with mobile phones has become a reality with the development of user terminalsÂ (e.g., mining for android.). Hence, blockchain-enabled FL needs to balance computational resource allocation between training and mining.

In this work, we propose a novel blockchain assisted decentralized FLÂ (BLADE-FL) architecture. In our BLADE-FL, training and mining processes are incorporated and implemented at each client, i.e., a client conducts both training and mining tasks with its own computing capability. The conventional framework that FL and blockchain are separated and respectively executed by training clients and miners can be deemed as a special case of resource allocation in our BLADE-FL. That is, in the conventional framework, a part of clients allocate all the computation resources for training, and the other part for mining only.

To be specific, we analyze an upper bound on the loss function to evaluate the learning performance of BLADE-FL. Then we optimize the computing resource allocation between local training and mining on a client to approach optimal learning performance. We also pay special attentions to a security issue that inherently exists in BLADE-FL, known as lazy clients problem. In this problem, lazy clients try to save their computing resources by directly plagiarizing models from others, leading to training deficiency and performance degradation. In this case, we explore the impact of lazy clients on the learning performance, and optimize Kğ¾K for minimizing the loss function.

The main contributions can be summarized as follows.

  • â€¢

    We propose a novel blockchain-assisted FL framework, namely, BLADE-FL, to overcome the issues raised by centralized aggregations in conventional FL systems. Compared with conventional blockchain-enabled FL, our BLADE-FL helps promote privacy against model leakage, and guarantees tamper-resistant model updates in a trusted blockchain network.

  • â€¢

    We analyze an upper bound on the loss function to evaluate the learning performance of BLADE-FL. In particular, we minimize the upper bound by optimizing the computing resource allocation between training and mining, and further explore the relationship among the optimal number of integrated rounds, the training time per iteration, the mining time per block, the number of clients, and the learning rate.

  • â€¢

    We focus on a lazy model for BLADE-FL, where the lazy clients plagiarize othersâ€™ weights and add artificial noises. Moreover, we develop an upper bound on the loss function for this case, and investigate the impact of the number of lazy clients and the power of artificial noises on the learning performance.

  • â€¢

    We provide experimental results, which are consistent with analytical results. In particular, the developed upper bound on the loss function is tight with reference to the experimental ones (e.g., the gap can be lower than 5%percent55\%), and the optimized resource allocation approaches the minimum of the loss function.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. SectionÂ 2 first introduces the background of this paper. Then we propose BLADE-FL in SectionÂ 3, and optimize the upper bound on the loss function in SectionÂ 4. Section 5 investigates the issue of lazy clients. Section 6 discusses the privacy issue. The experimental results are presented in SectionÂ 7. SectionÂ 8 concludes this paper. In addition, TableÂ I lists the main notations used in this paper.

2 Preliminaries

2.1 Federated Learning

In a FL system, there are Nğ‘N clients with the iğ‘–i-th client possessing the dataset Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i} of size |Di|subscriptğ·ğ‘–|D_{i}|, i=1,2,â€¦,Nğ‘–12â€¦ğ‘i=1,2,\dots,N. Each client trains its local model, e.g., a deep neural network, based on its local data and transmits the trained model to the server. Upon receiving the weights from all the clients, the server performs a global model aggregation. There are a number of communication rounds for exchanging models between the server and clients. Each round consists of an uploading phase where the clients upload their local models, and a downloading phase where the server aggregates the model and broadcasts it to the clients. Clients then update their local models based on the global one.

In the kğ‘˜k-th communication round, the server performs a global aggregation according to some combining rule, e.g., ğ’˜Â¯k=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nğ’˜iksuperscriptÂ¯ğ’˜ğ‘˜1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘–ğ‘˜\bar{\bm{w}}^{k}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\bm{w}_{i}^{k}, where ğ’˜iksuperscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘–ğ‘˜\bm{w}_{i}^{k} and ğ’˜Â¯ksuperscriptÂ¯ğ’˜ğ‘˜\bar{\bm{w}}^{k} denote the local weights of the iğ‘–i-th client and the aggregated weights, respectively. The global loss function is defined as Fâ€‹(ğ’˜Â¯k)=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1NFiâ€‹(ğ’˜Â¯k)ğ¹superscriptÂ¯ğ’˜ğ‘˜1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptÂ¯ğ’˜ğ‘˜F(\bar{\bm{w}}^{k})=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}F_{i}(\bar{\bm{w}}^{k})Â [30], where Fiâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–â‹…F_{i}(\cdot) is the local loss function of the iğ‘–i-th client. In FL, each client is trained locally to minimize the local loss function, while the entire system is trained to minimize the global loss function Fâ€‹(ğ’˜Â¯k)ğ¹superscriptÂ¯ğ’˜ğ‘˜F(\bar{\bm{w}}^{k}). The FL system finally outputs Fâ€‹(ğ’˜Â¯K)ğ¹superscriptÂ¯ğ’˜ğ¾F(\bar{\bm{w}}^{K}), where Kğ¾K is the overall communication rounds. Different from the training process in conventional DML systemsÂ [3], each client in FL only shares their local models rather than their personal data, to update the global model, promoting the clientsâ€™ privacy.

2.2 Blockchain

Blockchain is a shared and decentralized ledger. Thanks to the consensus mechanism, each transaction included in the newly generated block is immutable. The consensus mechanism validates the data within the blocks and ensures that all the nodes participating in the blockchain store the same data. The most prevalent consensus mechanism is Proof of WorkÂ (PoW), used in the Bitcoin systemÂ [12].

In Bitcoin, the process of the block generation is as follows. First, a node broadcasts a transaction with its signature to the blockchain network by the gossip protocolÂ [31]. Then the nodes in blockchain verify the transaction by the signature. Afterward, each node collects the verified transactions and competes to generate a new block that includes these transactions, by finding a unique, one-time numberÂ (called a nonce). This is to make the hash value of the data meet a specific target value. The node that finds the proper nonce is eligible to generate a new block and broadcasts the block to the entire network. Finally, the nodes validate the new block and append the verified block into the existing blockchainÂ [32].

Notably, the work in PoW is a mathematical problem that is easy to verify but extremely hard to solve. The nodes in the blockchain consume massive computing resources to figure out this complex problem. This process is called mining, and those who take part in it are known as miners. Because of the mining process, PoW can defense attacks on the condition that the total computing power of malicious devices are less than the sum of honest devicesÂ (i.e., 51% attack)Â [33].

3 Proposed Framework

In this section, we detail the proposed BLADE-FL framework in Section 3.1 and develop a computing resource allocation model in Section 3.2.

3.1 BLADE-FL

Our BLADE-FL system consists of Nğ‘N clients each with equal computing powerÂ (the computing power is measured by CPU cycles per second). In this distributed system, each client acts as not only a trainer but also a miner, and the role transition is designed as follows. First, each client (as a trainer) trains the local model, and then broadcasts the local model to the entire network as a requested transaction of the blockchain. Second, the clientÂ (as a miner) mines the block that includes all the local models that are ready for aggregation. Once the newly generated block is validated by the majority of clients, the verified models in the block are immutable. Without the intervention of any centralized server, each client performs the global aggregation to update its local model by using all the shared models in the validated block. Suppose that the uploading and downloading phases cannot be tampered with external attackers.

Let us consider that all the clients deploy the same time allocation strategy for local training and mining. In other words, all the clients start the training at the same time, and then turn to the mining stage simultaneously. In this context, for each global model update and block generation, we define an integrated round for BLADE-FL that combines a communication round of FL and a mining round of blockchain. As illustrated in Fig.Â 1, the kğ‘˜k-th integrated round can be specified as the following steps111In the very beginning of first integrated round, each client initializes its local parameters, such as initial weight, learning rate, etc...

{basedescript}\desclabelstyle\pushlabel\desclabelwidth

4em

Local Training. Each client performs the local training by iterating the learning algorithm Ï„ğœ\tau times to update its own model ğ’˜ik,âˆ€isuperscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘–ğ‘˜for-allğ‘–\bm{w}_{i}^{k},\forall i.

Model Broadcasting and Verification. Each client signs its models by the digital signature and propagates the models as its requested transactions. The other clients verify the transactions of the requested client (i.e., identity of the client).

Mining. Upon receiving the models from others, all the clients generate the global model and then compete to mine the kğ‘˜k-th block.

Block Validation. All the clients append the new block onto their local ledgers only if the block is validated.

Local Updating. Upon receipt of verified transactions in this block, each client updates its local model. Then the system proceeds to the (k+1)ğ‘˜1(k+1)-th round.

In contrast toÂ [20], BLADE-FL does not rely on an additional third-party for global aggregation, thereby promoting privacy against model leakage. From the above steps, the consensus mechanism builds a bridge between the local models from clients and the model aggregation. Thanks to PoW, BLADE-FL guarantees the tamper-resistant model update in a trusted blockchain network.

4 Performance Analysis of the BLADE-FL System

In this section, we evaluate the learning performance of BLADE-FL with the upper bound on the loss function in Section 4.1, and optimize the learning performance with respect to the number of integrated rounds in Section 4.2.

4.1 Achievable Upper Bound Analysis

Existing works such as [3]-[11] evaluated the learning performance of the standard FL based on the loss function, where a smaller value of the loss function corresponds to a learning model with higher accuracy. Recently, the work inÂ [36] derived an upper bound on the loss function between the iterations of local training and global aggregation.

Compared with the standard FL, our BLADE-FL replaces the centralized server with a blockchain network for global aggregation. Notably, the training process and the aggregation rule are the same as the centralized FL. Thus, the derived upper bound on the loss function in [36] can be applied to BLADE-FL.

We make the following assumption for all the clients.

Assumption 1.
  1. 1.

    Fiâ€‹(ğ’˜)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ’˜F_{i}(\bm{w}) is convex [37], i.e., Fâ€‹(ğ’˜)â‰¥Fâ€‹(ğ’˜â€²)+âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ’˜â€²)Tâ€‹(ğ’˜âˆ’ğ’˜â€²)ğ¹ğ’˜ğ¹superscriptğ’˜â€²âˆ‡ğ¹superscriptsuperscriptğ’˜â€²ğ‘‡ğ’˜superscriptğ’˜â€²F(\bm{w})\geq F(\bm{w}^{\prime})+\nabla F(\bm{w}^{\prime})^{T}(\bm{w}-\bm{w}^{\prime});

  2. 2.

    Fiâ€‹(ğ’˜)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ’˜F_{i}(\bm{w}) is Î¾ğœ‰\xi-Lipschitz [38], i.e., â€–Fiâ€‹(ğ’˜)âˆ’Fiâ€‹(ğ’˜â€²)â€–2â‰¤Î¾â€‹â€–ğ’˜âˆ’ğ’˜â€²â€–2subscriptnormsubscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ’˜subscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptğ’˜â€²2ğœ‰subscriptnormğ’˜superscriptğ’˜â€²2\|F_{i}(\bm{w})-F_{i}(\bm{w}^{\prime})\|_{2}\leq\xi\|\bm{w}-\bm{w}^{\prime}\|_{2};

    Fiâ€‹(ğ’˜)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ’˜F_{i}(\bm{w}) is L-smooth [37], i.e., â€–âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ’˜)âˆ’âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ’˜â€²)â€–2â‰¤Lâ€‹â€–ğ’˜âˆ’ğ’˜â€²â€–2subscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ’˜âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptğ’˜â€²2ğ¿subscriptnormğ’˜superscriptğ’˜â€²2\|\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w})-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}^{\prime})\|_{2}\leq L\|\bm{w}-\bm{w}^{\prime}\|_{2}.

4.2 Optimal Computing Resource Allocation

First, the following theorem shows the optimal solution that minimizes Gâ€‹(K)ğºğ¾G(K).

Theorem 3.

Given any fixed Î±ğ›¼\alpha, Î²ğ›½\beta, Nğ‘N (or Î´)\delta) and Î·ğœ‚\eta, the optimal number of integrated rounds that minimizes the upper bound on the loss function in (4) is given by

Kâˆ—=tsum2â€‹Î±â€‹Î²Î·â€‹L+Î±â€‹Î²+Î²2,superscriptğ¾superscriptğ‘¡sum2ğ›¼ğ›½ğœ‚ğ¿ğ›¼ğ›½superscriptğ›½2K^{*}=\frac{t^{\mathrm{sum}}}{\sqrt{\frac{2\alpha\beta}{\eta L}+\alpha\beta+\beta^{2}}}, (6)

when Î·â€‹Lâ€‹Î³Kâ‰ª1much-less-thanğœ‚ğ¿ğ›¾ğ¾1\frac{\eta L\gamma}{K}\ll 1.

Proof:

Please see Appendix C.

Then, under a fixed constraint tsumsuperscriptğ‘¡sumt^{\mathrm{sum}}, let us focus on the effect of Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta on Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*} under fixed Nğ‘N and Î·ğœ‚\eta by the following corollary333The following analytical results in Corollary 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 are with respect to Kğ¾K. Due to the fundamental tradeoff between Kğ¾K and Ï„ğœ\tau, the opposite results with respect to Ï„ğœ\tau also hold. .

Corollary 1.

Given Nğ‘N and Î·ğœ‚\eta, the optimal value Kğ¾K decreases as either Î±ğ›¼\alpha or Î²ğ›½\beta goes up. In this case, more time is allocated to training when Î±ğ›¼\alpha gets larger or to mining when Î²ğ›½\beta becomes larger.

Proof:

This corollary is a straightforward result from Theorem 3.

Recall that Î±ğ›¼\alpha denotes the training time per iteration, and Î²ğ›½\beta denotes the mining time per block. From Corollary 1, the longer a local training iteration takes, the more computing power allocated to the local training at each client. Similarly, each client allocates more computing power to the mining when the mining time is larger.

Next, we investigate the impact of Nğ‘N and Î·ğœ‚\eta on Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*} when Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta are fixed by the following corollaries (i.e., Corollary 2 and Corollary 4).

Corollary 2.

Given fixed Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta, Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*} becomes larger as Î´ğ›¿\delta grows. In this case, more time is allocated to the mining.

Proof:

Please see Appendix D.

Corollary 3.

Given fixed Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta, Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*} becomes smaller as Nğ‘N grows. In this case, more time is allocated to the training.

Proof:

Based on Corollary 2, the proof of Corollary 3 is straightforward, since Î´ğ›¿\delta drops as Nğ‘N grows.

The explanation of Corollary 3 is that each client may have trained an accurate local model but not an accurate global modelÂ (Î´ğ›¿\delta is large), and thus BLADE-FL needs to perform more global aggregation especially when Nğ‘N is small. This paper considers a number of honest clients in BLADE-FL to defend the malicious mining [40]. When Nğ‘N is sufficiently large, Î´ğ›¿\delta converges to its mean value according to the law of large number. In this context, Corollary 2 shows that Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*} approaches a constant as Î´ğ›¿\delta converges, and further implies that Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*} is independent of Nğ‘N.

Corollary 4.

Given fixed Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta, Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*} increases as Î·ğœ‚\eta goes larger. Meanwhile, the upper bound in (4) drops as Î·ğœ‚\eta grows if Î·â€‹L<1ğœ‚ğ¿1\eta L<1.

Proof:

Please see Appendix E.

The reason behind Corollary 4 is that the global model may not converge when each client is allocated with limited learning resources and a small learning rate. In addition, a higher learning rate may lead to faster convergence but a less inaccurate local model. To compensate for the inaccurate training, more computing power is allocated to the local training. In practice, the learning rate is decided by the learning algorithm, and the learning rates of different learning algorithms are diverse. Therefore, we can treat Î·ğœ‚\eta as a constant in BLADE-FL.

5 Performance Analysis with Lazy clients

Different from the conventional FL, a new problem of learning deficiency caused by lazy clients emerges in the BLADE-FL system. This issue is fundamentally originated from the lack of an effective detection and penalty mechanism in an unsupervised network such as blockchain, where the lazy client is able to plagiarize models from others to save its own computing power. The lazy client does not contribute to the global aggregation, and even causes training deficiency and performance degradation. To study this issue, we first model the lazy client in Section 5.1. Then, we develop an upper bound on the loss function to evaluate the learning performance of BLADE-FL with the presence of lazy clients in Section 5.2. Next, we investigate the impact of the ratio of lazy clients and the power of artificial noises on the learning performance in Section 5.3. In this section, suppose that there exist Mğ‘€M lazy clients in BLADE-FL and Mâ‰¤Nğ‘€ğ‘M\leq N. Let us define the lazy ratio as MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N}.

5.1 Model of Lazy Clients

A lazy client can simply plagiarize other models before mining a new block. To avoid being spotted by the system, each lazy client adds artificial noises to its model weights as

ğ’˜iâ€²k=ğ’˜ik+ğ§i,iâ€²âŠ†â„³,iâŠˆâ„³,k=1,2,â€¦,K,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ’˜superscriptğ‘–â€²ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘–ğ‘˜subscriptğ§ğ‘–formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘–â€²â„³formulae-sequencenot-subset-of-nor-equalsğ‘–â„³ğ‘˜12â€¦ğ¾\bm{w}_{i^{\prime}}^{k}=\bm{w}_{i}^{k}+\mathbf{n}_{i},\quad i^{\prime}\subseteq\mathcal{M},i\nsubseteq\mathcal{M},k=1,2,\dots,K, (7)

where â„³â„³\mathcal{M} denotes the set of lazy clients, ğ§isubscriptğ§ğ‘–\mathbf{n}_{i} is the artificial noise vector following a Gaussian distribution with mean zero and variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}. As Fig.Â 2 illustrates, the iğ‘–i-th client is identified as the lazy client if it plagiarizes an uploaded model from others and add artificial noise onto it in Step â‘ . Except the plagiarism in Step â‘ , the lazy clients follow the honest clients to perform Step â‘¡-â‘¤.

5.2 Achievable Upper Bound with Lazy Clients

In this subsection, we develop an upper bound on the loss function with the lazy ratio and the power of artificial noise in the following theorem.

Theorem 4.

Using the model of lazy clients in (7), an upper bound on the loss function after Kğ¾K integrated rounds with the lazy ratio of MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N} is given by

Fâ€‹(ğ’˜~K)âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğ’˜Â¯âˆ—)â‰¤G~â€‹(K,Î±,Î²,Î·,Î´,tsum,Î¸,Ïƒ2)=1Î³â€‹(Î·â€‹Ï•âˆ’Î´â€‹Î¾â€‹KLâ€‹(Î»Î³Kâˆ’1)âˆ’Î·â€‹Î¾â€‹Î´â€‹Î³+Kâ€‹Î¾â€‹MNâ€‹Î¸+Kâ€‹Î¾â€‹MNâ€‹Ïƒ2Îµ2â€‹Î³),ğ¹superscript~ğ’˜ğ¾ğ¹superscriptÂ¯ğ’˜~ğºğ¾ğ›¼ğ›½ğœ‚ğ›¿superscriptğ‘¡sumğœƒsuperscriptğœ21ğ›¾ğœ‚italic-Ï•ğ›¿ğœ‰ğ¾ğ¿superscriptğœ†ğ›¾ğ¾1ğœ‚ğœ‰ğ›¿ğ›¾ğ¾ğœ‰ğ‘€ğ‘ğœƒğ¾ğœ‰ğ‘€ğ‘superscriptğœ2superscriptğœ€2ğ›¾\begin{split}&F(\tilde{\bm{w}}^{K})-F(\bar{\bm{w}}^{*})\leq\tilde{G}(K,\alpha,\beta,\eta,\delta,t^{\mathrm{sum}},\theta,\sigma^{2})\\ &=\frac{1}{\gamma\left(\eta\phi-\frac{\frac{\delta\xi K}{L}\left(\lambda^{\frac{\gamma}{K}}-1\right)-\eta\xi\delta\gamma+K\xi\frac{M}{N}\theta+K\xi\frac{\sqrt{M}}{N}\sigma^{2}}{\varepsilon^{2}\gamma}\right)},\end{split} (8)

where ğ’˜~Ksuperscript~ğ’˜ğ¾\tilde{\bm{w}}^{K} denotes the aggregated weights of BLADE-FL with lazy clients after Kğ¾K integrated rounds, and Î¸=â€–ğ’˜iâ€²Kâˆ’ğ’˜~iâ€²Kâ€–2ğœƒsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ’˜superscriptğ‘–â€²ğ¾superscriptsubscript~ğ’˜superscriptğ‘–â€²ğ¾2\theta=\|\bm{w}_{i^{\prime}}^{K}-\tilde{\bm{w}}_{i^{\prime}}^{K}\|_{2} denotes the performance degradation caused by lazy clients after Kğ¾K integrated rounds.

Proof:

Please see Appendix F.

Thereafter, we use the upper bound inÂ (8) to evaluate the learning performance of BLADE-FL with lazy clients.

5.3 Optimization on Performance with Lazy Clients

Practically, a lazy node tends not to add either huge or tiny noise in order to conceal itself. To this end, it is required that the value of Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is comparable to that of Î¸ğœƒ\theta.

Remark 1.

From (8), the plagiarism behavior contributes a term proportional to MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N} to the bound, while the artificial noise exhibits an impact term proportional to MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{\sqrt{M}}{N}. This indicates that the plagiarism has a more significant effect on the learning performance compared with the noise perturbation.

Then, we analyze the impact of MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N} and Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} on the optimal value of Kğ¾K in the following corollary.

Corollary 5.

The optimal Kğ¾K that minimizes G~â€‹(â‹…)~ğºâ‹…\tilde{G}(\cdot) in (8) decreases as either the lazy ratio MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N} or the noise variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} grows.

Proof:

Please see Appendix G.

When the system is infested with a large number of lazy clients (i.e., the lazy ratio MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N} approaches 1), more computing power should be allocated to local training to compensate for the insufficient learning.

6 Discussions on Privacy Issue

In BLADE-FL, each client can add noise into local model as differential privacyÂ (DP) mechanism [9] to meet the need of privacy. For example, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP mechanism provides a strong criterion for the privacy preservation schemes. Here, Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0 is the distinguishable bound of all outputs on neighboring datasets ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime} in a database. A larger Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon gives a clearer distinguishability of neighboring datasets and thereby a higher risk of privacy violation. The definition of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP mechanism is as follows.

Definition 2.

(Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DPÂ [41]): A randomized mechanism â„³:ğ’³â†’â„›:â„³â†’ğ’³â„›\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} with domain ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} and range â„›â„›\mathcal{R} satisfies Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP, if for all measurable sets ğ’®âŠ†â„›ğ’®â„›\mathcal{S}\subseteq\mathcal{R} and for any two adjacent datasets ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²âˆˆğ’³ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²ğ’³\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X},

Prâ€‹[â„³â€‹(ğ’Ÿ)âˆˆğ’®]â‰¤eÏµâ€‹Prâ€‹[â„³â€‹(ğ’Ÿâ€²)âˆˆğ’®].Prdelimited-[]â„³ğ’Ÿğ’®superscriptğ‘’italic-ÏµPrdelimited-[]â„³superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²ğ’®\emph{Pr}[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})\in\mathcal{S}]\leq e^{\epsilon}\emph{Pr}[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})\in\mathcal{S}]. (9)

The inner privacy issue can be referred to privacy preserving schemes for decentralized FL in other worksÂ [42, 43]. When applying DP mechanism into BLADE-FL, we add a Gaussian noise with a small variance. Note that the DP mechanism solves the privacy leakage problem of FL, while our scheme solves the robust learning problem. These two problems are different and can be treated separately. Besides, based on the developed upper bound in TheoremÂ 4, we derive that a small noise does not affect the optimal integrated round. The optimal computing power allocation stays the same whether add DP or not. Thus, Clients in BLADE-FL can use DP mechanism to promoting their privacy without affecting the optimal computing power allocation of the system. We show the experimental results in Subsection 7.4.

7 Experimental Results

In this section, we evaluate the analytical results with various learning parameters under limited computing time tsumsuperscriptğ‘¡sumt^{\mathrm{sum}}. First, we evaluate the developed upper bound in (4), and then investigate the optimal value of overall integrated rounds Kğ¾K under training time per iteration Î±ğ›¼\alpha, mining time per block Î²ğ›½\beta, number of clients Nğ‘N, learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta, the ratio MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N}, and power of artificial noise Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}.

7.1 Experimental Setting

1) Datasets: In our experiments, we use two datasets for non-IID setting to demonstrate the loss function and accuracy versus different values of Kğ¾K.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet MNIST. Standard MNIST handwritten digit recognition dataset consists of 60,000 training examples and 10,000 testing examples. Each example is a 28Ã—\times28 sized handwritten digit in grayscale format from 0 to 9.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Fashion-MNIST. Fashion-MNIST for clothes has 10 different types, such as T-shirt, trousers, pullover, dress, coat, sandal, shirt, sneaker, bag, and ankle boot.

2) FL setting. Each client progresses the learning of a Multi-Layer PerceptronÂ (MLP) model. The MLP network has a single hidden layer that contains 256 hidden units. Each unit applies softmax function and rectified linear units of 10 classesÂ (corresponding to the 10 digits in MNIST and 10 clothes in Fashion-MNIST).

3) Parameters setting. In our experiments, we set the total computing time tsum=100superscriptğ‘¡sum100t^{\mathrm{sum}}=100, the samples of each client |ğ’Ÿi|=512,âˆ€isubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–512for-allğ‘–|\mathcal{D}_{i}|=512,\forall i, the number of clients N=20ğ‘20N=20, the mining time per block Î²=10ğ›½10\beta=10, the number of lazy clients M=0ğ‘€0M=0, and the learning rate Î·=0.01ğœ‚0.01\eta=0.01 as default, where the time is normalized by the training time per iteration Î±ğ›¼\alpha.

7.2 Experiments on Performance of BLADE-FL

Fig.Â 3 plots the gap between the developed upper bound in (4) and the experimental results. We set learning rate Î·=0.005ğœ‚0.005\eta=0.005 and lazy ratio MN=0.4ğ‘€ğ‘0.4\frac{M}{N}=0.4 in conditions (a) and (b), respectively. First, we can see that the developed bound is close but always higher than the experimental one under both conditions. Second, both the developed upper bound and the experimental results are convex with respect to Kğ¾K, which agrees with Theorem 2. Third, both the upper bound in (4) and the experimental results reach the minimum at the same optimal value of Kğ¾K.

Fig.Â 4 plots the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of Î±ğ›¼\alphaÂ (some curves are relatively short due to the limited total computing time), while TableÂ II shows the optimal training time and corresponding accuracy. Here, we set Î²=6ğ›½6\beta=6. First, Fig.Â 4(a) shows that larger Î±ğ›¼\alpha leads to larger loss function. This is due to the fact that both Kğ¾K and Ï„ğœ\tau from (3) drops as Î±ğ›¼\alpha grows. Second, from TableÂ II, the longer a training iteration consumes, the more training time each client takes. For example, using MNIST, the training time increases from 404040 to 646464 as Î±ğ›¼\alpha rises from 111 to 555. This observation is consistent with Corollary 1.

Fig.Â 5 plots the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of Î²ğ›½\betaÂ (some curves are relatively short due to the limited total computing time), while TableÂ III shows the optimal mining time and corresponding accuracy. First, Fig.Â 5(a) shows that larger Î²ğ›½\beta leads to larger loss function, since both Kğ¾K and Ï„ğœ\tau from (3) drops as Î²ğ›½\beta grows. Second, from TableÂ III, Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*} reduces as Î²ğ›½\beta rises, but the optimal mining time Î²â€‹Kâˆ—ğ›½superscriptğ¾\beta K^{*} goes up as Î²ğ›½\beta rises. For example, using MNIST, the mining time increases from 606060 to 727272 as Î²ğ›½\beta grows from 666 to 121212. This observation agrees with Corollary 1.

Fig.Â 6 shows the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of Nğ‘N, while TableÂ IV illustrates the optimal mining time and corresponding accuracy. We set Î²=6ğ›½6\beta=6. First, from TableÂ IV, we notice that the optimal mining time drops as Nğ‘N increases, which is consistent with Proposition 3. For example, using MNIST, Î²â€‹Kâˆ—ğ›½superscriptğ¾\beta K^{*} drops from 707070 to 505050 as Nğ‘N rises from 101010 to 252525. Second, from Fig.Â 6(a), larger Nğ‘N leads to lower loss function. This is because the involved datasets are larger as Nğ‘N grows, which causes a smaller loss function. Third, from both Fig.Â 6(a) and (b), Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*} approaches a fixed value when Nğ‘N is sufficiently large (e.g., N>20ğ‘20N>20). This observation is in line with Corollary 3.

Fig.Â 7 plots the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of Î·ğœ‚\eta, while TableÂ V illustrates the optimal mining time and corresponding accuracy. First, from TableÂ V, we find that the optimal mining time rises as Î·ğœ‚\eta grows, which is in line with Corollary 4. For example, using MNIST, Î²â€‹Kâˆ—ğ›½superscriptğ¾\beta K^{*} rises from 545454 to 727272 as Î·ğœ‚\eta grows from 0.0050.0050.005 to 0.10.10.1. Second, from Fig.Â 7(a), the loss function drops as Î·ğœ‚\eta increases except Î·=0.1ğœ‚0.1\eta=0.1. This is because Î·ğœ‚\eta grows significantly when Î·â€‹L<1ğœ‚ğ¿1\eta L<1, and our developed upper bound is no longer suitable. For example, when Î·>0.05ğœ‚0.05\eta>0.05, the loss function increases as Î·ğœ‚\eta rises in our experiments for both MNIST and Fashion-MNIST.

7.3 Experiments on Performance with Lazy Clients

Fig.Â 8 plots the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of lazy ratio MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N}, while TableÂ VI shows the optimal training time and corresponding accuracy. We set the power of artificial noise Ïƒ2=0.01superscriptğœ20.01\sigma^{2}=0.01. First, from TableÂ VI, it is observed the optimal training time steps up as MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N} increases. For example, using MNIST, the time allocated to training rises from 303030 to 505050 as MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N} increases from 0%percent00\% to 30%percent3030\%. This observation is consistent with Corollary 5. Second, from Fig.Â 8(a), the learning performance degrades as MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N} grows. This is because more lazy clients involved in the system as MNğ‘€ğ‘\frac{M}{N} grows, leading to lower training efficiency.

Fig.Â 9 plots the experimental results of the loss function and accuracy on MNIST and Fashion-MNIST for different values of values of Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}, while TableÂ VII shows the optimal training time and corresponding accuracy. We set MN=20%ğ‘€ğ‘percent20\frac{M}{N}=20\%. First, from TableÂ VII, we notice that the optimal training time Ï„â€‹Î±â€‹Kâˆ—ğœğ›¼superscriptğ¾\tau\alpha K^{*} grows as Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} increases, which agrees with Corollary 5. For example, using MNIST, Ï„â€‹Î±â€‹Kâˆ—ğœğ›¼superscriptğ¾\tau\alpha K^{*} grows from 303030 to 505050 as Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} increases from 0.010.010.01 to 0.30.30.3. Second, from Fig.Â 9(a), the learning performance of BLADE-FL (i.e., loss function and accuracy) degrades as the noise power Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} goes larger.

7.4 Experiments of Differential Privacy Mechanism

Based on [9], we have the relationship between Gaussian noise variance and the privacy budget Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. Then, we apply local differential privacy on each client by adding random Gaussian noises on the uploaded models in each integrated round. We show the experiments of various Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon versus the optimal integrated rounds, the optimal loss function and accuracy in Fig.Â 10 and Fig.Â 11.

Fig.Â 10 plots the experimental results of the optimal integrated round, loss function and accuracy on MNIST for different values of values of privacy budget Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. The Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon of differential privacy algorithm represents the privacy budget [41] (a smaller Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon leads to a higher level of privacy protection). First, we notice that the optimal loss function decreases as Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon increases, while the optimal accuracy grows up. That is, the higher privacy budget leads to a lower learning performance. Second, from Fig.Â 10, we observe that the optimal integrated round is not related to Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. In this way, the method of privacy protection does not affect the optimal computing power allocation of BLADE-FL, which is consistent with the discussion of privacy of BLADE-FL in Section 6. Therefore, clients in BLADE-FL can use privacy protection algorithm to meet the privacy needs without changing their own optimal computing power allocation.

The testing accuracies of the Fashion-MNIST and Cifar-10 dataset are plotted in Fig.Â 11 with respect to different privacy level Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. This figure shows that the system achieves a higher performance with a larger value of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. However, a larger Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon implies that the system is under a weaker privacy protection.

8 Conclusions

In this paper, we have proposed a BLADE-FL framework that integrates the training and mining process in each client, to overcome the single-point-failure of centralized network and maintain the privacy promoting capabilities of the FL system. In order to evaluate the learning performance of BLADE-FL, we have developed an upper bound on the loss function. Also, we have verified that the upper bound is convex with respect to the total number of integrated rounds Kğ¾K and have minimized the upper bound by optimizing Kğ¾K. Moreover, we have investigated a unique problem in the proposed BLADE-FL system, called the lazy client problem and have derived an upper bound on the loss function with lazy clients. We have included experimental results, which have been seen to be consistent with the analytical results. In particular, the developed upper bound is close to the experimental results (e.g., the gap can be lower than 5%percent55\%), and the optimal Kğ¾K that minimizes the upper bound also reaches the minimum of the loss function in the experimental results.

A few directions of future works are discussed as follows. First, it is of interest to design an efficient incentive mechanism for BLADE-FL that encourages all clients to actively follow the protocol. Second, another challenging issue of BLADE-FL is to detect plagiarism behaviors and discourage lazy clients. The detection of lazy clients will be addressed in our future work.

Appendix E Proof of Corollary 4

FromÂ (27), we know that Î©Î©\Omega increases as the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta rises, which leads to larger xğ‘¥x. Thus, from the proof of Corollary 2, Kâˆ—superscriptğ¾K^{*} descends as Î·ğœ‚\eta ascends. Then the derivative of the function gâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘”â‹…g(\cdot) with respect to Î·ğœ‚\eta is

where Î·â€‹L<1ğœ‚ğ¿1\eta L<1. It indicates that the loss function decreases as rate Î·ğœ‚\eta increases if Î·â€‹L<1ğœ‚ğ¿1\eta L<1. In this case, gâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘”â‹…g(\cdot) is not an increasing function with respect to Î·ğœ‚\eta, resulting in larger loss function. This completes the proof.
